element.name: Spellblade
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: A human runs her hand across their blade tracing esoteric patterns that alight at a touch, flames flickering alive in their wake casting a sudden blazing light over the gloomy cavern, creatures of the dark shrinking back from the fire’s light. A gnome’s eyes begin to glow as a massive greatsword of energy condenses into their waiting hand, forming a blade of pure energy, twice their height but weightless in their hands. The edgy elf vanishes from sight, teleporting behind their foe before muttering something cryptically and cutting them down.

A Spellblade combines magic and martial talent in a perfect blend, able to blend their use of them into a single art. Rather than being a Wizard that happens to be good with a sword or a Fighter that knows some magic, a Spellblade is defined by their ability to merge the spells and martial talents into a single strike: a Spellstrike.

Becoming a Spellblade isn’t an accident—it’s a difficult path to master and requires intense concentration and conditioning to master fluidly casting spells in the storm of battle in perfect sync with your attacks. Spellblades are, consequently, almost always driven by some form of motivation that have made them strive for this unique style of perfection. Some view it as an art or tradition important to them, some view it as the ultimate weapon to overcome a great obstacle, and some pursue it because of the challenge itself, seeking to prove themselves.

Spellblades are uncommon, requiring an unusual degree of talent to master their arts compared to those that choose to focus and specialize in only one of their two challenging fields. Adventurers are already a rare breed, but Spellblades are rarer still, which often causes them to defy expectations. A bookish and mild Spellblade may be surprisingly nimble or strong, while one that may look a musclebound oaf may be surprisingly erudite.

The most important place to start when making a Spellblade is knowing what drew your character to this difficult and rare path. The path of a Spellblade is one that has few mundane uses—they are not scholars and their skills serve little purpose outside the adventuring arts, so what drove your character to master these? There’s an intentionality to a Spellblade similar to that which might be found in a Paladin.
You can make a Spellblade quickly by following these suggestions.
If you wish to follow the technique of the Aether Blade, Battlemage, or Flying Sword, put your highest ability score in Intelligence, followed by Dexterity, and then Constitution.
If you wish to follow the technique of the Guardian or Spellfist, put your highest ability score in Strength, followed by Constitution, and then Intelligence.
If you wish to follow the technique of the Mage Hunter, Rimeblade, Spellshot, or Swiftblade, put your highest ability score in Dexterity, followed by Intelligence, and then Constitution.
As a spellblade, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Dice: 1d8 per spellblade level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per spellblade level after 1st
Armor: Light armor, medium armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Saving Throws: Constitution, Intelligence
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Arcana, Athletics, History, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Religion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: a martial weapon
(a) a light crossbow and quiver of 20 bolts or (b) any two simple weapons
(a) scale mail or (b) leather armor
(a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack
An arcane focus

description.p: Alternatively, you may start with 5d4 × 10 gp to buy your own equipment.

element.name: Arcane Surge
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Your affinity for magic gives you a pool of Arcane Surges. Once during your turn, you can expend a use of Arcane Surge to do any of the following:

ul.li: Detect Magic. Cast detect magic without expending a spell slot.

Teleport. Teleport up to 5 feet to an unoccupied space you can see (no action required). This distance increases by 5 feet at 5th (10 feet), 9th (15 feet), 13th (20 feet), and 17th (25 feet) levels.

element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Additionally at 1st level, you learn one cantrip of your choice from the Spellblade class list. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this cantrip.

element.name: Spellcasting
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: As part of your study of magic, you gain the ability to cast spells at 2nd level. The spells you learn are limited in scope, primarily concerned with enhancing your abilities and devastating your foes.

At 2nd level, you learn two additional cantrips of your choice from the Spellblade spell list. You learn additional Spellblade cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Spellblade table. The table includes the bonus cantrips gained from Spellblade class features (such as Empowered Strike).

The Spellblade table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your Spellblade spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of your Spellblade spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
description.h4: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
description.p: You know three 1st-level spells of your choice from the Spellblade spell list. The Spells Known column of the Spellblade table shows when you learn more Spellblade spells of your choice.
Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the Spellblade spells you know and replace it with another spell from the Spellblade spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Spellblade spells. Your magic comes from a practitioner’s knowledge of the arcane and training. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for an Spellblade spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

center.p: Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

description.p: You can use an arcane focus as a spellcasting focus for your Spellblade spells.

element.name: Spellstrike
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, you can infuse spells into your weapon. As a bonus action, you can cast a 1st level or higher Spellblade spell with a casting time of 1 action in a special way, infusing it into a melee weapon instead of having it immediately take effect. The next time you make a melee attack with that weapon before the end of your turn, the spell is cast against the target of the attack. The spell fizzles and fails to cast if you cast another spell before attacking.
Spellstrike’s interaction with the spell mechanics is determined by the spell’s effect:

ul.li: Attack Rolls. If the spell requires an attack roll (melee or ranged) it automatically hits the target if the weapon attack hits and misses the target if the weapon attack misses.

Saving Throws. If the spell has a saving throw, it automatically deals damage as if the target failed its saving throw against the spell on hit, but if it has any effects besides dealing damage, the target makes the save against those effects as normal for being targeted by the spell (regardless if the attack hits or misses). If a spell does half damage to targets that pass their save, they take half damage on a missed attack, treating it as if they had passed their saving throw. If a spell always hits (such as magic missile), the spell hits regardless if you hit or miss your attack.

Area of Effect. If the spell has an area of effect, that area of effect must include the space the target of the Spellstrike is in, be placed such that one edge of it is within the range of your weapon, and otherwise follows the rules of the spell regarding placement and range. Other creatures caught in the area of effect treat the spell as if you had cast it normally. The target is not affected by the spell again (having already resolved as part of the attack).

Multiple Attack Rolls. Spells that have multiple attack rolls (such as scorching ray or crackleK) tie the outcome of only the first attack roll to the melee weapon attack. You resolve all subsequent attack rolls of the spell as if you had cast the spell, but can ignore the disadvantage on ranged attack rolls from being within 5 feet of hostile creatures when doing so.

description.p: You can only cast spells that are on the Spellblade class list using Spellstrike, and can only cast them at a level you can cast them as a Spellblade, though you can use any spell slot you have available to cast the spell.

Critical Strikes. If the attack critically strikes, a spell that has a spell attack roll used with spell strike also critical strikes, but a spell that has a saving throw just treats it the same as a hit (inflict wounds would critical strike, but fireball would not, as it cannot critically strike). Condition Sequence. Any effects that require the target to fail a saving throw take place after the attack. For example, if you spellstrike hold person, the saving throw against being paralyzed (and the condition if they fail) take place after the attack roll is complete. Area of Effect. One edge of the spell must be in range of the weapon, but the center point of the spell does not need to be. For example, with spellstriking fireball, you don’t need to hit yourself with. One edge of the spell must be within range, and the target must be inside the area of effect, but the center point of the spell can further away.

element.name: Arcane Deflection
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: At 2nd level, you learn the shield spell, incorporating it into your Aegis. It doesn't count against your number of spells known, and you can cast it without expending a spell slot once, after which you must expend a spell slot as normal until you complete a short or long rest.

sheet.description: You can cast shield spell once without expending a spell slot.

element.name: Aegis
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Additionally at 2nd level, you start to form a magical Aegis that enhances your physical powers with magical powers, blending them together. You can select one 1st level slot Aegis effect (listed at the end of the class) and gain the effects.

When you complete a long rest, you can change your selected 1st level slot Aegis effect or further boost your Aegis by sacrificing spell slots, granting magical empowerments that last until you complete your next long rest. When you do so, select an additional Aegis Effect (listed at the end of the class document) and expend the listed level of spell slot.

You can expend a maximum number of spell slot levels this way equal to your Spellblade level divided by four (rounded up, for example, at 5th level you can expend two levels of spell slots this way, while at 9th level you can expend three levels of spell slot, etc.).

The level listed for an Aegis spell is the level of spell slot sacrificed to gain the feature. A spell slot sacrificed for an Aegis feature cannot be regained until the Aegis Spell effect is removed during a long rest. You can select any Aegis feature from the list, up to the maximum number of total spell slot levels you can spend on this feature.

You can have a maximum number of spell slot levels sacrificed equal to the highest slot you have from the Spellblade class. You can only sacrifice spell slots you have, and have gained from the Spellblade class.
Aegis effects are not spells and cannot be dispelled as such.

sheet.description: You can select one 1st level slot Aegis effect and gain the effects. When you complete a long rest, you can change your selected 1st level slot Aegis effect or further boost your Aegis by sacrificing spell slots, granting magical empowerments that last until you complete your next long rest. When you do so, select an additional Aegis Effect and expend the listed level of spell slot. You can expend a maximum number of spell slot levels this way equal to {{levelquarter}}. You can have a maximum number of spell slots sacrificed equal to {{spellbladeslot}}. You can only sacrifice spell slots you have, and have gained from the Spellblade class. Aegis effects are not spells and cannot be dispelled as such.

element.name: Spellblade Technique
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: When you reach 3rd level, you select a specialization for your powers. You can choose from the Battlemage, Aether Blade, Guardian, Mage Hunter, Swiftblade, or Spellshot techniques, each of which grants you additional features.
Your choice grants you features at 3rd level, and again at 7th, 15th, and 20th level.

element.name: Ability Score Improvement
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

element.name: Empowered Strike
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Beginning at 5th level, you can use cantrips on the Spellblade class list with your Spellstrike feature.

You learn 2 additional cantrips of your choice, selecting the options from the Spellblade cantrip list, and an additional cantrip at 9th, 13th, and 17th level (these additional cantrips are included on the Spellblade table).

sheet.description: You can use cantrips on the Spellblade class list with your Spellstrike feature.

element.name: Arcane Recuperation
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Starting at 6th level, you gain the ability to regain some of your magical energy through a quick focused meditation. When you finish a short rest, you regain some of your expended spell slots. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than one third of your Spellblade level (rounded down). You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.
Additionally, at any time, as a bonus action you can expend a spell slot to regain Arcane Surges equal to the level of spell slots spent.

sheet.description: When you finish a short rest, you regain some of your expended spell slots. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than one third of your Spellblade level (rounded down). Additionally, at any time, as a bonus action you can expend a spell slot to regain Arcane Surges equal to the level of spell slots spent.

element.name: Magical Warding
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Additionally at 6th level, you gain proficiency in your choice of Wisdom or Charisma saving throws, and you automatically succeed on saving throws against your own spells.

sheet.description: You automatically succeed on saving throws against your own spells.

element.name: Archetypal Magic
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: At 10th level, you can cast each of the spells granted by your Spellblade technique without expending a spell slot once. After you cast a spell that way, you cannot cast it that way again until you complete a long rest.

sheet.description: You can cast each of the spells granted by your Spellblade technique without expending a spell slot once. After you cast a spell that way, you cannot cast it that way again until you complete a long rest.

element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Starting at 10th level, when you finish a long rest you can select an additional 1st Level Aegis Effect to gain the benefit of without expending a spell slot. This effect lasts until you complete a long rest, at which time you can select a new effect.
At 14th level, you can additionally select one 2nd level Aegis Effect this way, and at 18th level, you can additionally select one 3rd level Aegis effect this way.

element.name: Splash Damage
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Beginning at 11th level, when you hit a creature with Spellstrike, the target and creatures of your choice within 5 feet of the target that would be hit by the same attack roll take 1d8 additional force damage.
On a miss, the target takes half as much damage, and nearby creatures take no damage (even if the attack roll would have hit them).

sheet.description: when you hit a creature with Spellstrike, the target and creatures of your choice within 5 feet of the target that would be hit by the same attack roll take 1d8 additional force damage. On a miss, the target takes half as much damage, and nearby creatures take no damage (even if the attack roll would have hit them).

element.name: Blast Zone Immunity
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Starting at 11th level, you are immune to the area of effect of your own spells. You take no damage from them, and ignore all other affects unless you choose to be affected.

sheet.description: You are immune to the area of effect of your own spells. You take no damage from them, and ignore all other affects unless you choose to be affected.

element.name: Surging Focus
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Starting at 14th level, if you fail a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration on a spell, you can spend an Arcane Surge to succeed instead.

sheet.description: If you fail a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration on a spell, you can spend an Arcane Surge to succeed instead.

element.name: Magical Sensitivity
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Additionally at 14th level, you learn the detect magic spell, and it does not count against your spells known, and the detect magic spell no longer requires concentration for you.

For the duration of detect magic, you gain proficiency in the Arcana skill. If you are already proficient in the Arcana skill, for the duration you gain expertise, allowing you to add double your proficiency bonus to ability checks made using the Arcana skill.

sheet.description: The detect magic spell no longer requires concentration for you. For the duration of detect magic, you gain proficiency in the Arcana skill. If you are already proficient in the Arcana skill, for the duration you gain expertise, allowing you to add double your proficiency bonus to ability checks made using the Arcana skill.

element.name: Blast Zone Control
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: At 18th level, when use Spellstrike to cast a spell that affects an area of effect, you can expend a use of your Arcane Surge expand the effect of your Blast Zone Immunity to a number of allies equal to your Intelligence modifier. When used this way, it only protects your allies until the start of your next turn, at which point they go back to being affected by any ongoing effects of a spell.

element.name: Arcane Swiftness

element.name: Elemental Enchantment

element.name: Enchanted Shield
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You touch a shield making it easy to wield. You have proficiency with that shield during the effect.

element.name: Surging Saves

element.name: Warding Barrier
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You reduce all damage taken by 1.

element.name: Weapon Focus

description.p: You turn your weapon into an arcane focus for your Spellblade spells.

element.name: Arcane Eyes
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You gain the ability to see in the dark. You have darkvision out to a range of 60 feet during the effect.

element.name: Arcane Style
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: While this Aegis is active, you gain one Fighting Style option of your choice from the Fighter class. If you already have a style, the one you choose must be different.

element.name: Arcane Skill

description.p: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

element.name: Blade Channel
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

element.name: Illusionary Ally
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: When you roll initiative, you create a single duplicate as per the mirror image spell. You can only have one duplicate at a time from this effect. If you cast mirror image during the effect, the spell remains the same, but the first time an image is lost, this duplicate is destroyed instead.

element.name: Loyal Weapon
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: A weapon you touch as part of selecting this Aegis is under the effect of returning weapon.

element.name: Quickened Movement
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Your movement speed is increased by 5 feet.

element.name: Aether Barrier
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: When you deal damage with your Aether Blade, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier.

element.name: Arcane Overflow
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You gain an additional use of your Arcane Surge feature.

element.name: Arcane Shield
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You can create a shield of arcane power that protects you, blocking incoming attacks. You gain a +2 to AC as if you had a shield equipped. This counts as an equipped shield but does not require the use of your hand, and you cannot benefit from both this and an equipped shield.

element.name: Blastwave
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Whenever you teleport using an Arcane Surge or a spell of 1st level or higher spell during the effect, your Aegis sends out a wave of power. Creatures of your choice within 5 feet of your destination must make a Strength saving throw against your Spell Save DC or be knocked prone.

element.name: Chameleon Aegis
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You can hide without cover, and do not become immediately revealed when in line of sight of a creature. If you move while a creature can see you, you must pass an additional Dexterity (Stealth) check to remain hidden.

element.name: Contingent Blink
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: The first time you would drop to 0 hit points as a result of taking damage, you instead drop to 1 hit point, and vanish from your plane of existence, appearing on the Ethereal Plane. At the start of your turn, you return to an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see within 10 feet of the space you vanished from. Once triggered, this cannot be triggered again until you complete a long rest.

element.name: Reflective Aegis
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You have advantage on saving throws against spells that effect a line, and when you pass a saving throw against a spell that deals damage, you reflect part of the damage causing the caster to take half the damage failing the spell save would have dealt to you.

element.name: Arcane Resistance
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You gain resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage during the effect. You may select a new damage type when you select this Aegis again.

element.name: Combat Contingency
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You incorporate a contingency for rapidly deploying combat magic into your Aegis. When you roll initiative, as a reaction you can cast one spell of 3rd level or lower spell that affects only you and has a casting time of 1 action.

element.name: Dimensional Pathways
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: When you use Arcane Surge to teleport, you can take one willing Medium or smaller creature within 5 feet of you with you, teleporting them to within 5 feet of your destination.

element.name: Phantom Aegis
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You can move in brief bursts of intangibility. You can move through the spaces of other creatures (allied or hostile) without any penalty to your movement, and can pass through objects and nonmagical barriers as thick as 1 inch.

element.name: Runic Strength
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: Your Strength score becomes equal to your Intelligence score during the effect.

element.name: Arcane Flight
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You gain a flying speed of 30 feet during the effect.

element.name: Arcane Alacrity
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: When you take the Attack action, you can attack twice, instead of once.

element.name: Resilient Aegis
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You gain proficiency in one Saving Throw of your choice during the effect.

element.name: Stone Aegis
element.source: Kibbles' Compendium of Legends and Legacies

description.p: You reduce all damage taken by 5
